name: kummerowia-striata
wildlife-value: Seeds are eaten by game birds and songbirds. The foliage is eaten by deer and other herbivores.
edibility: Lespedeza is commonly used as forage in pastures.  It may be grazed or cut for hay when in 1/2 bloom stage.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Fruits are 0.2 inch long legumes and each contain a single seed.
flower-description: 1/4 inch long 5 petaled flowers appear in the leaf axils in groups of 1-3. They can be upright or horizontal. The shape is similar to pea flowers with the lower petal being pink or purple and the to smaller upper petals are white. Bloom time is mid-summer for 1-2 months.
leaf-description: The alternate compound leaves are trifoliate with leaflets being Â¼-1" long and about one-third to one-half as much across. The leaflets are broadly oblong-elliptic to oblong-obovate in shape and margins are entire.
stem-description: The stems are purplish with appressed white hairs that point downward.
uses: It is used as forage, hay, and green manure to enrich the soil as it fixes nitrogen.
